open_questions.description: What is Redis?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is Redis?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.

referenceAnswers.text: Redis is an open-source, in-memory data structure store that can be used as a database, cache, message broker, and streaming engine. It supports various abstract data structures such as strings, hashes, lists, sets, sorted sets, bitmaps, hyperloglogs, geospatial indexes, and streams.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: In-Memory Storage: Data is stored in memory for fast read/write operations. Data Structures: Supports strings, lists, sets, sorted sets, hashes, bitmaps, etc. Persistence: Options for RDB snapshots and AOF logging. Replication: Master-slave replication for high availability. Pub/Sub: Built-in publish-subscribe messaging. Clustering: Automatic partitioning across multiple nodes. Transactions: Support for atomic execution of commands.

open_questions.title: You use Redis over a traditional
open_questions.description: Why would you use Redis over a traditional relational database?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Why would you use Redis over a traditional relational database?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Performance: Redis operates in-memory, providing sub-millisecond latency for reads/writes, ideal for caching and real-time applications. Data Structures: Offers rich data types like lists and sets for efficient operations without complex queries. Scalability: Easier horizontal scaling with clustering and replication compared to relational DB sharding. Use Cases: Better for caching, session management, pub/sub, where relational features like ACID transactions are not strictly needed. Simplicity: No schema required, flexible for rapidly changing data models.

open_questions.description: What are Redis lists and how are they used?

Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.

referenceAnswers.text: Redis lists are ordered collections of strings, implemented as linked lists, allowing efficient insertions/removals from both ends. Usage: Queues (LPUSH/RPOP), stacks (LPUSH/LPOP), recent items lists, task queues. python import redis r = redis.Redis(decode_responses=True) key = "tasks" # Producer – enqueue three jobs in one call r.rpush(key, "resize:img1", "resize:img2", "resize:img3") # Consumer – FIFO blocking loop while (job := r.blpop(key, 0)): # 0 = wait indefinitely print("Processing", job[1])
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Redis sets are unordered collections of unique strings, supporting operations like unions, intersections, differences. When to Use: Tagging systems, unique visitor tracking, friend lists where order doesn't matter and duplicates are avoided. python import redis r = redis.Redis(decode_responses=True) # define two follow-sets r.sadd("user:42:follows", "alice", "bob", "dora") r.sadd("user:17:follows", "bob", "carl", "dora", "ellen") # who do both users follow? mutual = r.sinter("user:42:follows", "user:17:follows") print("Mutual follows:", mutual) # {'bob', 'dora'} # quick membership test print("alice in user-17’s list?", r.sismember("user:17:follows", "alice")) # False

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Format: RDB is compact binary snapshot; AOF is log of commands. Durability: AOF more durable with frequent fsync; RDB can lose data since last snapshot. Size: RDB smaller; AOF larger but can be rewritten. Recovery Time: RDB faster to load; AOF slower as commands are replayed. Overhead: RDB forks process for snapshot; AOF appends continuously.

referenceAnswers.text: MULTI starts transaction, queues commands. EXEC executes all queued commands atomically, returns results. DISCARD cancels transaction. python import redis r = redis.Redis(host="localhost", port=6379, decode_responses=True) # ---------- Successful transaction ---------- pipe = r.pipeline() # pipeline defaults to MULTI/EXEC mode pipe.set("greeting", "hi") pipe.incr("visit_count") results = pipe.execute() # -> ["OK", 1] print("EXEC results:", results) # ---------- Cancelling a transaction ---------- pipe = r.pipeline() pipe.set("greeting", "bye") # …some runtime check fails, so abort: pipe.reset() # equivalent to DISCARD print("Transaction discarded; greeting is still:", r.get("greeting"))
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice
